sourceDesc.p: Produced from collation output prepared in batch file processing on 2023-10-29 21:01:48.555295 .
Edited to correct alignments and prepared for the Frankenstein Variorum spine on 2023-11-30T21:49:23.332187-05:00.

body.div:
Walton in continuation.
August
1
3
You
have read this strange & terrific story,
Marg e a ret
and
^
do not you
feel your blood
con
gealed
with
horror Mine of ten did as he
related it
like that
which even
now curdles
mine – When Sometimes seized with
^
sudden agony
he
could not continue
or his
tale,
at
others
his voice
broken
yet
piercing described some of the scenes
uttered the words
of which it is
composed. he had passed through –
His fine & lovely
eyes
^
were now lighted up
^
with
indignation or
now subdued
by
^
to downcast
sorrow
& infinite wretchedness. Sometimes
he commanded his countenance &
tones
and related the most horrible incidents
with a
smothered tranquil
voice
suppressing every
mark of
indi agitation – and then
like a vol
cano bursting
forth
his face would sud
denly change to an expression of the
wildest
rage
as he shrieked
forth
out
his imprecations
of ^ on
hi m s
persecutor.
His tale is
connected
& told with
an appearance of the simplest
truth
yet I own to you
my sister that the
letters of Felix &
Maimouna
^
Safie
which he
shewed
me
& the apparition of the
monster
seen from our
ship
brought
to me a greater conviction of the
fact truth
of his narrative
than his
asserverations—
however earnest & connected.
Such a monster
did has then really exist ence, I could not
cannot doubt
it
yet I
was am
lost in
surpri z s e &admira
tion.
Sometimes I endeavoured to gain
from
Frankenstein the particulars of his formation
but on this point he was impenetrable. Are you
mad, my friend,
said
he,
or
whither does your
senseless curiosity lead
you –Would
you also
create for yourself
& for the world a dæmonical
ene n m y or to what does your questions
tend.
Peace,
peace;
learn my
miseries &
do
not seek to
encrease
your
own.
Frankenstein discovered that I
detail
ed or made notes concerning his
history
he
asked to see
them
& himself corrected
^
and augmented them
in many
places
but principally in
guv
giving the life & spirit
of
the
the conver
sations he held with his
enemies–Since
you have
made an account
^
said
he I
would
not that a mutilated one should go down to
posterity.
Thus
have ten days
passed
away
while I have listened to the strangest
tale that ever imagination formed.
My
thoughts
& every feeling of my
soul
&
ha
have been drunk up by the
interrest
I felt in
for my
guest ^
which this
x tale, & his
own elevated
& gentle
man
ners
have
created
I wish
ed to soothe
him
yet
could can I
tell counsel one so infinitely
miserable.
Whose mind continually dwelt on horrors
so destitute of every hope of
consolation
to
live ? Oh no – the only joy he could feel
can now
feel know
was will be
in when he
compos in es g his shattered mind
^
feelings
to
peace &
death —
Yet
one feeling he
enjoys,
one comfort, the
sourse offspring
of solitude
&
delirium —
he
tho believed that
when
in dreams he
saw holds converse with
his friends,
who consoled
& derives from
that communion
consolation for
his
miseries
or
instigated him excitement
to
^
his
vengeance
that they
were are not the creations of his
fancy but the real beings that he saw
beheld
and conversed with
who visit
him from
the regions
of a
remoter world –This
faith
g a i ve s
a solemni
ty to his reveries that
made render
ed
them
peculiar ly
interresting. to
me,
almost as imposing
&inte
resting
as truth.
Our conversations
have are
not always
been confined to his own history &
misfortunes–
and
o O n
every point of general literature he
displays unbounded
knowledge
and a quick
& piercing apprehension. His eloquence is
forcible &
touching
nor can I hear
him
when
he
narrates
a pathetic
incident
or endea
vours to move the passions of pity
& love
without
tears. What a glorious creature must
this he
have been in
his
days of
prosperity
when
he is thus noble & godlike in
ruin –
He seems
to feel his own
worth
& the greatness of
his fall.
I have felt, said he, great &
When younger,
said he,
I felt as if I was destin
ed for some great enterprize.
My feelings
are
profound
but I possessed a coolness of
judge
ment
that fitted me for
gr an eat d
enter
prises
illustrious
atchievements .
This sentiment of the worth of my
nature supported
me
when others would
have
sunk
for I deemed it criminal
to throw away in useless
grief;
those ta
lents that might be useful to my
fellow creatures –
When I reflected on the
work
that I had
compleated,
no less a one
than the creation of a sensitive
&
rational animal
I could not rank my
self with the herd of common projectors.
But this
feeling
which supported me
only
now serves
^
only to
sink plunge
me lower in
^
the
dust—
All
my speculations & hopes are as
nothing and
like the
Archangel who aspired to
omnipotence
I am
now
chained in an eternal hell. My imagination
was
vivid
yet my
app powers of application
were
in
tense –
by the union of these qualities I
ex conceived
the
idea
and executed the
desig creation of a
man–
Even now I cannot
recollect
without
passion
my reveries while the work was
incomplete –I
trod heaven in my
thoughts –
now exulting
in my
powers –
now
wi burning with the idea
of their
consequen s c es.
From my infancy I was
imbued with high hopes and a lofty
ambition
but how am I
sunk – Oh
my
friend –
if you had
know m n
me as I once
was who
you would
not
recognize
me
even in this
misery
^
state of
dgr degradation
Despon
dancy
rarely visited my
heart
a high destiny
seemed to bear me on,
untill
I
fe e l l oh, never
never
^
again to
rise" again .
Must I lose this creature
^
admirable being ? I have
longed for a
friend,
I have sought one who would
sympathize
with & love me.
Behold
on these
desart
seas
I have found
one such
an one – but
I
fear
I have gained him
but
to know his
value
& lose
him –I
would
reconcile him
with life
but he repulses the
thought.
"I thank
you,"
Walton," he said,
but
When for
your kind intentions
towards
so
miserable a
wretch –
but when you speak
of new
connections ties
and
think fresh
affections
think you that any
can replace those
I have lost . which
are gone? Can any man
be to me as Clerval
was
or any woman ano
ther
Elizabeth.
Even where the affections are
not strongly moved by any superior
excel
lence
the companions of our childhood al
ways possess a certain power over our
mind
that
hardly any
other later friend can
obtain. They know our infantine
feelings
which
however they may be afterwards
modified
are never
entirely changed
^
eradicated
and they
can judge of our actions with
greater
certainty –
A sister or brother can never, un
less indeed such
symtoms
have been
shewn
early
suspect the other of fraud or false
dealing
when another
friend
however
strongly he may be
attatched may feel be in
spite of himself
invaded
by
suspicion.
But I enjoyed
friends
dear not only
by
association
but
for
their
e own sake –and
wherever I
am
the soothing voice of my
Eliszabeth or
the conversation of
Cler
val
will be ever whispered
to
^
in
my ear.
They are
dead
& but one feeling
could can in
such a
situation solitude
keep me alive
persuade me to preserve my life . If I
w h ere
engaged in any high undertaking
or
design
fraught with extensive uti
lity to my
fellow creatures
then could I
live to fulfil
it—But
such is not my
destiny –I
must pursue & destroy the
creature
being
to whom I gave
existence
then
my
task
will be
fulfilled
& I may
die.
